title: Homogeneity of Populations Chi-Square Test
question_text:
A car rental company is conducting a study regarding the types of car preferred by customers at the company’s various locations. The table below summarizes the reservations over a seven-day period at three of the company’s locations.
Type of CarCompactStandardFull SizeOtherTotal
$\text {Location } 1$$70$$75$$40$$59$$244$
$\text {Location } 2$$80$$78$$47$$62$$267$
$\text {Location } 3$$96$$64$$68$$51$$279$
The company is willing to consider the $244$ reservations at Location $1$ as a random sample from the set of all reservations at Location $1$, the $267$ reservations at Location $2$ as a random sample from the set of all reservations at Location $2$, and the $279$ reservations at Location $3$ as a random sample from the set of all reservations at Location $3$.
If a significance level of $0.05$ is used, does these data provide sufficient evidence to indicate a difference in the distributions of the car types between the populations of reservations at the three locations?

choices.text:
Yes, because the
P
-value is less than
0.01
.

Yes, because the
P
-value is less than
0.05
.

Yes, because the
P
-value is greater than
0.05
.

No, because the
P
-value is greater than
0.05
.

No, because the
P
-value is greater than
0.95
.
